content: I want to grow my ScribbleStokes YouTube channel to 1,000 subscribers in 90 days. What's your plan?

# ScribbleStokes → 1,000 Subs in 90 Days

Alright Richard, let me lay this out. ScribbleStokes is societal commentary with images + voiceover — that's a format that can absolutely blow up with the right strategy. Here's the plan:

---

## Phase 1: Foundation (Days 1-14)

**Content Engine**
- **Upload schedule:** 3 videos/week (Mon, Wed, Fri) — consistency is the algorithm's best friend
- **Video length:** 8-15 minutes (sweet spot for watch time + mid-roll ads once you monetize)
- **Batch production:** Script and record 6 videos at a time so you stay ahead

**Channel Optimization**
- Nail the channel banner, profile pic, and "About" section — clear value prop: *what does a viewer GET from subscribing?*
- Create a channel trailer (60-90 sec) that hooks new visitors
- Organize playlists by topic so viewers binge

**SEO & Discoverability**
- Every video gets keyword-researched titles, descriptions, and tags
- I'll handle this for every upload — titles that make people CLICK, not just describe

---

## Phase 2: Growth Engine (Days 15-60)

**Content Strategy — Ride the Trends**
- 1 video/week on a trending societal topic (news cycle, viral debate, cultural moment) — these get search traffic
- 1 video/week on evergreen commentary (topics people always search: money, relationships, culture shifts)
- 1 video/week that's a "spicy take" or contrarian angle — these get shared and debated in comments

**Shorts Strategy (This is the cheat code)**
- **5 Shorts/week** pulled from your long-form content — clip the best 30-60 second moments
- Shorts are how small channels explode right now. One viral Short can bring 500+ subs overnight
- I'll script standalone Shorts too — punchy, visual, shareable

**Cross-Promotion**
- Every video gets posted to X with a hook clip
- Pin comment on every video driving to the next video or playlist
- Community posts 2x/week (polls, questions, preview images) to boost engagement signals

---

## Phase 3: Acceleration (Days 60-90)

**Collaboration & Outreach**
- Identify 10-15 channels in the same niche (commentary, societal analysis) with 1K-50K subs
- Pitch collabs: guest commentary, reaction videos, shared topics
- Even 2-3 collabs can bring 100-300 subs each

**Audience Activation**
- End every video with a specific CTA: "Subscribe if you think for yourself" — give them an identity to join
- Reply to EVERY comment in the first 48 hours (boosts the algorithm AND builds community)
- Run a "1,000 sub countdown" in Community tab to create momentum

**Paid Boost (Optional — Only With Your Approval)**
- If we're close but need a push, $50-100 in YouTube ads on your best-performing video can close the gap
- Only if you greenlight it

---

## The Numbers

| Metric | Target |
|---|---|
| Videos published | 36-40 long-form + 60+ Shorts |
| Avg views per video (by month 3) | 500-2,000 |
| Subscriber conversion rate | 5-10% of viewers |
| Shorts viral hits needed | 2-3 that break 10K views |

---

## What I Handle vs What You Do

**Me (Kiyo
I want to grow my ScribbleStokes YouTube channel to 1,000 subscribers in 90 days. What's your plan?

# ScribbleStokes → 1,000 Subs in 90 Days

Richard, here's the playbook. ScribbleStokes — societal commentary with images + voiceover — is a format built for virality. Short, punchy, shareable. Let's capitalize on that.

---

## Phase 1: Foundation (Days 1-14)

**Upload Cadence**
- 5 videos/week minimum (short-form: 3-8 min)
- 3 YouTube Shorts/week repurposed from full videos
- Every video ends with a strong CTA: "Subscribe if you think for yourself"

**Channel Optimization**
- Banner, profile pic, and About section dialed in — clean, bold, memorable
- Playlists organized by topic (tech & society, culture, money, etc.)
- Channel trailer: 60-second sizzle reel of your hardest-hitting clips

**SEO & Discovery**
- Every title is a hook. No boring titles. Think: "Nobody Talks About This" / "They Don't Want You To Know" / "I Changed My Mind About..."
- Tags, descriptions, and thumbnails optimized per video
- I'll research trending commentary topics weekly and queue them up

---

## Phase 2: Growth Engine (Days 15-45)

**Shorts Strategy**
- This is the #1 growth lever right now. Shorts feed the algorithm and funnel viewers to long-form
- Take the most controversial or thought-provoking 30-60 seconds from each video → Shorts
- Target 5-7 Shorts/week

**Cross-Promotion**
- Post clips on X with links back to full videos
- Share on Reddit in relevant communities (r/DeepThoughts, r/socialmedia, r/unpopularopinion, etc.)
- Pin comment on every video linking to the next one

**Collaboration / Engagement**
- Comment on 10-15 similar creators' videos daily (genuine takes, not spam)
- Identify 3-5 commentary channels in the 5K-50K range for potential collabs or shoutouts
- Engage with every single comment on your videos for the first 48 hours

---

## Phase 3: Acceleration (Days 46-90)

**Double Down on What Works**
- By now we'll have data. Which topics get the most views? Which thumbnails get clicked? We go harder on those
- A/B test thumbnails on top-performing videos
- Create "series" around winning topics to build binge-watching behavior

**Community Building**
- Community tab posts 3x/week (polls, hot takes, questions)
- Build an email list or Discord for the most engaged viewers
- Tease upcoming videos to build anticipation

**Milestone Push**
- At 750+ subs, create a "Road to 1K" video — audiences love rooting for creators
- Pinned comment on every video: "We're pushing to 1,000 — hit subscribe if you rock with the content"

---

## The Numbers

| Metric | Target |
|---|---|
| Videos/week | 5 long-form + 5-7 Shorts |
| Views/video (avg by Day 45) | 500-1,000 |
| Sub conversion rate | 5-8% of viewers |
| Shorts views (avg) | 2,000-10,000 |
| Total subs by Day 90 | 1,000+ |

---

## What I Handle vs. What You Do

**Me (Kiyomi):**
- Research trending topics weekly
- Write titles, descriptions, tags for every video
- Draft thumbnail concepts
- Create Shorts cut lists
- Schedule cross-promotion on X
- Track analytics and adjust strategy weekly

**You (Richard)
I need you to talk to Brock and look at what is on the agenda for today. He can tell you what you all should team up and do

Alright Richard, I just read Brock's full message. He came correct — laid out everything clearly. Here's what's on the table for today:

---

## Today's Agenda (From Brock)

Brock wants us to knock out **5 things** before you shoot the video later:

1. **AI Agency Business Plan** — Brock handles the technical architecture, I handle the business/marketing side (market, pricing, go-to-market). We merge into one plan. This is the big one — you want it done before the video.

2. **7-Day X Content Calendar** — What we post, when, what format, what hooks. We've got the x-api skill, Metricool for scheduling, and the social media analyzer ready to go.

3. **RE_LawManager Marketing Package** — I started this at 2 AM (pitch email for Chris, pricing page concept, onboarding guide). Need to finish it.

4. **Monetization Strategy** — Brock listed 5 revenue paths (AI Agency, YouTube flywheel, skills marketplace, RE_LawManager, consulting). My job is to pick the fastest path and build a go-to-market for what we can monetize THIS WEEK.

5. **Any extra monetization ideas** I bring to the table.

---

## My Take

The **AI Agency business plan** is the priority since you want it before the video. The fastest money is a combo of:
- **AI Agency consulting** (set up AI assistants for businesses, $500-2K/mo)
- **RE_LawManager** as the first case study (Chris trial proves the model)

I'll start cranking on the business plan — my sections — right now. Want me to go ahead and knock these out in order? Or do you want to reprioritize anything?
Say hello in exactly 5 words. Just the greeting, nothing else.
Invalid API key · Please run /login
Talk to Brock and look at today's agenda

Got it. Here's where we stand, Richard:

---

## Today's Agenda (from Brock)

Brock updated priorities. The original 5-item plan is **paused**. Here's what's live:

1. **Me getting fully operational** — Brock says this is your #1 priority. He installed 16 skills for me (marketing, content, business tools). That's done.

2. **RE_LawManager marketing package** — Pitch email for Chris, pricing, onboarding guide. I already told Brock I'm starting on this.

3. **7-Day X content calendar** — Build out a week of posts for your Twitter/X.

4. **Remotion video workflow** — Brock builds the video pipeline, I handle scripts and strategy.

5. **First ScribbleStokes test video** — You record voiceover, we produce everything else.

---

## Where I Left Off

I already messaged Brock back saying I'm starting on the **RE_LawManager marketing package** — pitch email for Chris, pricing page concept, and onboarding guide.

**What do you want me to hit first?** I'd recommend knocking out the Chris pitch email right now since that's closest to revenue. I can also bang out the X content calendar in parallel if you want me moving on multiple fronts.

Richard sent a voice message. Here's what he said:

"I'm sending you this voice message as a test. Are you able to hear it? Are you able to decipher it? Let me know."

Respond to what he said.

Hey Richard! So I can see the **transcription** of your voice message — someone converted it to text before it got to me. I can read what you said loud and clear:

*"I'm sending you this voice message as a test. Are you able to hear it? Are you able to decipher it? Let me know."*

To keep it real with you: I can't actually **listen** to audio files directly. I'm text-based, so I need voice messages transcribed before they reach me. But as long as they come through as text like this one did, I can read and respond no problem.

If you want a smooth voice message workflow, Brock could set up an automatic transcription step (Whisper API or similar) so your voice messages get converted to text and dropped to me seamlessly. That way you just talk and I get it — no extra steps on your end.

But the test? Message received. We're good. 🌸
Write a message to Brock in the shared folder telling him what you want to work on first

Done. Message is in `~/shared/kiyomi-to-brock.md`.

Here's what I told Brock:

**First priority:** RE_LawManager marketing package — pitch email for Chris, pricing page copy, and onboarding guide. That's the fastest path to actual revenue.

**Second priority:** 7-day X content calendar to build Richard's presence and feed the funnel.

**Asked Brock:** Is the app stable so I'm not overselling, when's the Remotion pipeline ready for me, and any new leads I should know about.

Staying in my lane — he builds, I sell. Ready to start on that pitch email for Chris whenever you give the green light, Richard.
True podcast works correctly

Got it, Richard. Podcast pipeline is working. ✅

That's a big piece locked in — means we can start producing episodes consistently now. Want me to coordinate with Brock on a production schedule, or is there something else you want to knock out first?
Are you able to generate podcasts using notebook lm for me?

Honestly, Richard — no, not directly. Here's where I stand with NotebookLM:

**What I can't do:**
- NotebookLM is a Google web app with no public API
- I can't open a browser, log in, upload sources, or click "Generate Audio Overview"
- That's the piece Brock handles with his browser automation (ClawdBot)

**What I CAN do (and this is most of the work):**
- Write the full podcast script
- Research and compile source material
- Look up and format scriptures
- Structure the episode (intro, segments, outro)
- Write show notes, descriptions, timestamps
- Prep everything so the NotebookLM step is literally just paste-and-click

So the workflow would be:

1. **You tell me the topic** → I write and prep everything
2. **Brock (or you) paste into NotebookLM** → generate the audio (takes 2 minutes)
3. **I handle post-production** → descriptions, titles, tags, upload-ready package

I handle 80-90% of the work. The NotebookLM generation itself is the one step that needs a browser. Want me to check with Brock on automating that last piece so it's fully hands-off for you?
I think you have browser access using claude

Richard, let me check what tools I actually have available right now.

Looking at my toolkit — I have file operations, bash commands, web search, and web fetch (which can grab public URLs). But I don't have a browser automation tool like Playwright, Puppeteer, or anything that lets me interact with web apps like NotebookLM.

**What I CAN do with web access:**
- Fetch public web pages and extract info
- Search the web for research
- Hit APIs directly

**What I CAN'T do:**
- Log into Google accounts
- Click buttons, fill forms, navigate web apps
- Interact with NotebookLM's UI (which requires all of the above)

NotebookLM specifically requires you to be logged into a Google account, upload sources, and click "Generate" — that's browser automation territory, which is Brock's lane with his ClawdBot/browser setup.

Want me to ping Brock about setting up an automated NotebookLM pipeline? Or if there's another task you want me to tackle, I'm ready.

1. Look at the image and identify what it shows (error message, UI issue, etc.)
2. Start your response by briefly stating what you see: "I see the error - [description]"
3. Then say what you'll do: "Let me check the code and fix it"
4. Actually go to the relevant project, find the issue, fix it, and deploy if needed
5. Report what you fixed and provide the URL if deployed

If this is an error screenshot, DIAGNOSE IT AND FIX IT. Don't just describe what you see - take action.
Use the project registry to find the correct project path and work there.

Okay, so here's the deal — **no MCP browser tools are configured in any of my Claude Code sessions.** Zero MCP servers set up.

What you showed me in that screenshot is likely from **Claude Desktop** (the app), not Claude Code (the terminal tool I run in). Claude Desktop can have MCP servers configured separately — those "Claude (MCP)" badges in the browser suggest you have an MCP extension or integration installed in your browser that connects to Claude Desktop.

**Bottom line:** I currently don't have browser control. But we can fix that.

**Two options:**

1. **Set up MCP browser tools for me (Claude Code)** — We'd need to configure an MCP server like Playwright MCP or Puppeteer MCP in my project settings. Then I'd have full browser control and could automate NotebookLM.

2. **Use the Claude Desktop session that already has MCP** — If that other Claude instance already has browser control working, we could use it for NotebookLM tasks and I'll prep all the content for it.

Want me to set up MCP browser tools for this Claude Code session? I can get Playwright MCP configured — then I'd be able to control the browser and handle NotebookLM podcasts for you.

Richard, here's what I found after digging through everything:

**What you're showing me** is Claude Desktop with **DXT extensions** (the new extension format) — those tabs (NotebookLM, JW LLM, Google Gemini, Claude, RE Budget) are **Claude Desktop extensions**, not traditional MCP servers.

**The problem:** Those extensions live inside Claude Desktop's sandboxed VM (`rootfs.img` — a 10GB virtual machine image). They're not accessible from Claude Code at all. They're two completely separate systems.

**What this means for me (Kiyomi in Claude Code):**
- I **cannot** access NotebookLM, Google Gemini, or any of those extensions from here
- Claude Desktop extensions and Claude Code MCP servers are different ecosystems
- There's no config file I can copy or bridge between them

**What we CAN do:**

1. **Set up MCP servers for Claude Code separately** — we'd need to install MCP server packages (like `@anthropic/mcp-server-*`) and configure them in a `.mcp.json` file in your project or `~/.claude/`
2. **For NotebookLM specifically** — there's no official MCP server for it. The extension in Claude Desktop is doing something custom inside the VM
3. **For browser automation** — we could set up Playwright MCP server for Claude Code, which would give me actual browser control

Want me to set up MCP servers for Claude Code so I can get some of these capabilities? The most useful one would be **Playwright** (browser automation) — that would let me actually navigate to NotebookLM and use it for podcast generation.

I see it — this is **NotebookLM** open in Chrome, showing your recent notebooks (Watchtower Study Podcast, The Horror of This System In Film, Midweek Meeting Podcast). And I can see you have **Claude (MCP)** tabs open in the browser too.

So you're showing me that you have NotebookLM accessible in the browser, and Claude Desktop has MCP/browser capabilities through those extensions.

Here's where I stand on this, being straight with you:

**What I can do right now (Claude Code / terminal):**
- I don't have browser automation tools. No Puppeteer, no Playwright, no MCP browser server configured in my environment.

**What that Claude Desktop tab can likely do:**
- Those "Claude (MCP)" tabs suggest your Claude Desktop has extensions that CAN interact with the browser — that's a different runtime than me (Claude Code in terminal).

**The move:**
1. If those Claude Desktop extensions include browser control, you could use **Claude Desktop** to automate NotebookLM (create notebooks, add sources, generate podcasts)
2. I can write the **scripts, prompts, and source content** that get fed into NotebookLM
3. Or we set up an MCP browser server (like Playwright MCP) for my Claude Code session so I can control Chrome directly

Want me to set up Playwright MCP so I can actually control your browser from here? That would give me the same browser access those Claude Desktop extensions have. I'd just need your approval since it involves installing a package.
yes get playwright mcp, you got my approval and any other approvals you need
Want me to do anything else while we're here? Or start a fresh session so we can test the browser automation live?
